Regardless of whether it gets fixed this time, I'm just going to use this laptop as a desktop, with an external keyboard and mouse. That way, I won't have to deal with the original machine at all. Previously, with other brands of laptops, as long as it wasn't human damage, even if it was out of warranty, they would fix it well, and customer service explained things very clearly. It seems the original poster also encountered a common issue with the new generation of AMD: when the graphics card is at full load, the CPU also reaches full load simultaneously. It's the same when the discrete graphics are off and integrated graphics are used, causing the CPU to directly downclock. Additionally, I recommend not using sleep mode; it's better to shut down the laptop directly when not in use and not plugged in, because if sleep mode fails, it usually won't last more than 2 hours. Many forum experts abroad have tested this and found no solution. The current best configuration is to disable small cores and run at a lower frequency when out and about, which is similar to the Intel i9 situation. When unplugged, just use power saving and disable small cores. I just want to vent that AMD's software, whether for graphics cards or CPUs, is truly terrible. If you want to test software, you can use Hyper-V, VirtualBox, VMware, Windows Sandbox... Install it inside these. If the virtual machine gets a virus, just delete the entire virtual machine + virtual hard drive, which is safer. I previously tested cracked software in a virtual machine and got a virus, so I just deleted the whole VM + hard drive, and my host machine was fine. Personally, I wouldn't recommend Win10/11 S mode; to be blunt, it's a monopolistic version. In S mode, you can't install .exe, .msi... nor can you use Chrome, Brave.... You can only install things from the Microsoft Store and use the Edge browser; you have no choice but to use Microsoft products. Generally, home computers come with the Home edition (you cannot stop forced updates). Commercial computers come with the Pro edition. Additionally, I personally feel antivirus software is unnecessary. Last year, I bought an M2 SSD online, which came with PCCillin 2021, but after installing it, I found it was constantly scanning for viruses, similar to the annoying Windows Defender. Just avoid clicking on programs from unknown sources. If you're still worried, you can right-click and use the built-in Defender to scan. Furthermore, for a document-focused laptop, choose an i3/r3 (above 16,000 NTD would be better) or higher. Lower-end Celeron/Pentium/Athlon are also suitable for documents, but only "barely usable" (priced around 10,000 NTD). In short, if you see a CPU with NXXXX on a shopping website, don't buy it, and eMMC is not recommended. If your budget is sufficient, buy i5/r5 or higher for better performance. The latest is 13th gen, but it's still a bit expensive. 11th or 12th gen is fine, but avoid 10th gen. Memory is usually pre-installed 8GB. If you want to expand, you need to check how much RAM that laptop supports maximum. I remember home computers generally support up to 16GB, while commercial/gaming computers support more. 8GB is a bit tight because Win11 uses 3-4GB RAM upon startup. It's recommended to expand to 16GB. For storage, an M.2 SSD is a must; HDD is optional. The screen is usually FHD. Commercial computers generally use better materials and usually have security features like fingerprint recognition and facial recognition; this is where they differ from home computers. Also, most home computers on the market "do not" include a bag or mouse, while commercial computers generally do; pay attention to this. Hope this helps!

This performance is normal. A 61Whr battery has to handle two power-hungry components: a 400-nit OLED screen and an Intel CPU. OLED is inherently less power-efficient than LCD. Additionally, Lenovo's laptops focus more on performance release than power saving, and their BIOS strategies are more aggressive, providing higher wattage whether idle or at full load. Of course, it can't compare to GRAM. To save power, you can only reduce brightness, enable dark mode, disable discrete GPU direct connection, and remove unused apps.

I've bought the Go 3 and Pro 5. The Go 3 is good, but the battery is too small. It only runs smoothly in high-performance mode, but it runs out of battery in less than 2 hours. The official keyboard is too small, causing me to often press the wrong keys when typing (no problem if you use an external standard-sized keyboard). I think the Pro 5 is good, but because the price for 128GB and above is too expensive, I ran out of space after a while and gave it to my family (although the Go 3 also has 128GB, it's enough space since my girlfriend uses it for documents).
